metadata.case_name: Firestone Tyre and Rubber Co. of India Ltd. v. Their Workmen (and State of Maharashtra v. Their Workmen)

facts.text: Respondents (workmen) addressed four demands to the company: gratuity, holidays, classification of certain employees, and unconditional bonus for financial year ended October 31, 1953.

Respondents union forwarded copy of demands to Assistant Commissioner of Labour (Conciliation Officer), Bombay, stating no hope of direct negotiations as company had not recognised the union, requesting commencement of conciliation proceedings.
Company declared bonus equivalent to 1/4 of basic earnings for year 1952-53.
Respondents informed company they accepted offered bonus without prejudice to their demand for higher bonus based on company's profits.
Conciliation Officer held preliminary discussion, admitted only two demands into conciliation: classification of certain employees and bonus for 1952-53; excluded gratuity and holidays.
Conciliation proceedings failed; Conciliation Officer made failure report under s. 12(4) on July 5, 1954.

In failure report, Conciliation Officer noted substance in respondents' bonus claim, suggested additional bonus to company (not accepted); opined classification demand consonant with practices in comparable concerns, though company cited liberal increments.
Government of Bombay considered report, refused reference under s. 12(5) on December 11, 1954, reason: workmen resorted to go-slow during 1952-53.
Respondents filed petition under Art. 226 in Bombay High Court on February 18, 1955, against State and company, seeking mandamus to refer dispute under ss. 10(1) and 12(5).
Tendolkar J. held s. 12(5) imposes obligation to refer if satisfied case for reference; reason extraneous; issued mandamus to reconsider ignoring go-slow.
State and company appealed; Chagla C.J. and Desai J. affirmed Tendolkar J., granted certificate.
During relevant year 1952-53, respondents adopted go-slow tactics for 5-7 months; clause 23(c) of standing orders makes willful slowing-down misconduct.
Disciplinary action taken against 58 workmen due to go-slow.
Despite go-slow, total production compared favourably with previous years; profits justified additional bonus claim.

legal_issues.text: Construction of s. 12(5) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947: whether 'may' means 'shall' if satisfied case for reference; whether government must refer or has wide discretion as under s. 10(1); whether reference under s. 12(5) independent of s. 10(1).
Whether reason for refusing reference (go-slow by workmen) is germane/relevant or extraneous/punitive.

petitioner_arguments.text: S. 12(5) does not convert 'may' into 'shall'; discretion as wide as under s. 10(1); government can consider all relevant facts including expediency; go-slow relevant as it shows lack of discipline, affects industrial peace.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 10(1), 12(5), 13 of Industrial Disputes Act; object of Act for industrial peace

petitioner_arguments.text: Reference power under s. 12(5) exercised via s. 10(1); s. 12(5) report not sole basis, other facts like go-slow can be considered.

respondent_arguments.text: 'May' in s. 12(5) means 'shall' as coupled with duty to record/communicate reasons; obligation to refer if prima facie case; go-slow extraneous to merits of bonus/classification claims.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S. 12(5) of Industrial Disputes Act; Reg. v. Tithe Commissioners

respondent_arguments.text: Refusal punitive; company paid bonus despite go-slow, took disciplinary action; production/profits justify claim.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Principles of industrial adjudication on bonus

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Act: s. 10(1) confers wide discretion for reference; s. 12(5) requires consideration of s. 12(4) report but not exclusively; ultimate reference under s. 10(1); government considers prima facie merits and relevant facts bona fide.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S. 12(5) does not independently confer reference power; discretion wide but based on relevant facts.

court_reasoning.text: Construction debate academic; both sides agree refusal invalid if reasons extraneous/irrelevant; mandamus lies if not bona fide or based on irrelevant facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reasons must be germane; court not in appeal but checks extraneous considerations.

court_reasoning.text: Go-slow reason wholly extraneous/punitive; irrelevant to classification claim; for bonus, profits justify; company paid bonus, disciplined workmen; not for government to punish via refusal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expediency cannot mask punitive action; merits prima facie exist per conciliator.

holdings.text: Under s. 12(5), government must consider conciliator's report and relevant facts; if prima facie case and no relevant bar, must refer; refusal valid only if reasons germane.
Go-slow not germane reason for refusing reference on bonus/classification; mandamus to reconsider ignoring it.

precedents_cited.relevance: Words empowering may be compulsory if for public benefit

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme for reference, conciliation, duties; discretion under s.10(1), obligation to reasons under s.12(5)

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ of mandamus against government for extraneous refusal

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeals, confirmed High Court order issuing mandamus directing government to reconsider reference under s.12(5) ignoring go-slow, considering only germane reasons.
outcome.relief_granted: Mandamus to State to reconsider making reference, ignoring go-slow fact.

key_quotes.text: "the main object of the Act is to provide for cheap and expeditious machinery for the decision of all industrial disputes by referring them to adjudication"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States purpose of Industrial Disputes Act

key_quotes.text: "if the Government is satisfied that a case for reference has been made out it may make such reference. If it is satisfied that a case for reference has not been made out it may not make such a reference but in such a case it shall record and communicate to the parties concerned its reasons therefor."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the impugned decision of the Government is wholly punitive in character and must in the circumstances be treated as based on a consideration which is not germane and is extraneous."
key_quotes.speaker: court
